newsitem.title: CHINA: HK future leader pledges fair vote after handover.
newsitem.headline: HK future leader pledges fair vote after handover.

text.p: Hong Kong's future leader Tung Chee-hwa on Friday pledged fair and open elections for the territory's legislature, but said the formula for filling legislative seats after China regains control had not been set.
"They (elections) will be open and based on the principle of fairness," Tung told a news conference in Beijing.

The man who will lead Hong Kong after the British colony reverts to Chinese rule at midnight on June 30 said he would study recommendations of a Beijing-appointed group known as the Preparatory Committee that has been designing the framework of the future government.
"I welcome the opportunity to make this difficult decision," Tung said.
The Preparatory Committee wound up a meeting in Beijing on Friday, handing Tung and the future regional government recommendations on how to fill the seats by both direct and indirect methods.
China has already made clear it will scrap the territory's existing directly elected legislature and replace it with an appointed provisional body.
Tung said he expected to see new legislative elections in the second quarter of 1998.
The Preparatory Committee recommended elected seats be filled either by a form of proportional representation or a multi-candidate race with several top vote-getters winning office.
Whatever formula Tung accepts, many of the territory's democratic activists will not be happy as they say it will make it harder for them to win a seat than under the current system.
Under a formula that China has endorsed, only 20 of the legislature's 60 seats will be elected directly, with the others filled by indirect vote or appointment.
The Preparatory Committee also made recommendations for 15 so-called "functional constituencies" or groups that will fill seats in indirect elections.
Tung will choose nine of those groups which will join 21 others.
One group on the recommended list, the Chinese enterprise association, has aroused controversy as it would appear to give further powers to China.
A senior Chinese official pronounced the work of the Preparatory Committee as largely completed but said the group would not yet disband.
"We can say the (Preparatory Committee's) task is basically over," Chen Ziying, deputy director of the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office under the State Council, or cabinet, told reporters.
Chen said, however, a decision on when the Preparatory Committee will be disbanded was up to the National People's Congress, China's parliament.
